title: 105_s448
content: The Act is titled the "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" and it amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act by adding a new section regarding interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" restricts out-of-state waste disposal at landfills or incinerators unless authorized by the affected local government through formal written approval. The affected local government must require the owner or operator of a waste facility to provide detailed information, including a description of the facility, waste capacity, anticipated quantities of waste, and a map showing the site location and features. The owner or operator of a waste facility must provide detailed information including site location, environmental characteristics, controls for runon or runoff management, air pollution control devices, methane monitoring, landfill covers, and monitoring programs. The owner or operator of a waste facility must provide detailed information on leachate collection systems, waste residuals management, site access controls, required permits, and personnel requirements for the facility. This includes estimates of increased truck traffic, skill and education levels needed for jobs, and employment statistics before and after the facility's operation. The owner or operator of a waste facility must provide information on environmental law violations, gifts and contributions, and compliance with solid waste management plans as required by State law. Prior to granting authorization for out-of-State municipal solid waste, the affected local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes, publish a notice in a newspaper, and hold a public hearing for comments in accordance with State law. The local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes of any authorization granted for out-of-State municipal solid waste. Public comment, including a public hearing, must be provided in accordance with State law. Landfills and incinerators in operation or under construction are exempt from this requirement if they received out-of-State waste shipments within the previous year. The local government must notify relevant parties of any authorization for out-of-State municipal solid waste. Landfills and incinerators must comply with federal and state laws regarding design, location, monitoring, and closure. Shipments of waste must be documented. The Governor has the authority to restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills by limiting the quantity received for disposal during a 1-year period. The landfill or incinerator owner must provide documentation of the shipment to the Governor. The Governor can restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills by limiting the quantity received for disposal during a 1-year period. The landfill must be in the state and the owner/operator exempt from certain requirements. Prior to requesting this limit, the affected local government and solid waste planning unit must follow procedural requirements. The affected local government and solid waste planning unit must provide notice, allow public comment, and take formal action regarding the disposal of out-of-state municipal solid waste. The Governor must respond consistently without discrimination based on landfill or state of origin. The Governor's authority is limited in this matter. The Governor's authority to dispose of out-of-state municipal solid waste is limited by State law and existing contracts. Landfill or incinerator owners must make their disposal contracts available for public inspection. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must provide a copy of each disposal contract for out-of-State municipal solid waste for public inspection. The contract must include information on waste volume, source, and duration. States can choose to be exempt from this requirement by notifying the Administrator and referencing the specific section. The section outlines the process for states to be exempt from certain requirements by notifying the Administrator and referencing the specific section. Definitions for "affected local government" and "affected local solid waste planning unit" are provided. The curr_chunk defines terms related to solid waste management planning, including "host agreement" and "municipal solid waste." Municipal solid waste is described as refuse generated from various sources, excluding hazardous waste. The curr_chunk defines terms related to solid waste management planning, including exclusions such as hazardous waste, industrial waste, medical waste, and recyclable materials. It also defines "out-of-State municipal solid waste" as waste generated outside of the State. The curr_chunk further clarifies the definition of "owner or operator" in relation to landfills or incinerators, excluding states or local governments that own or operate the facility within their jurisdiction, as well as individuals who only receive waste they generate. The curr_chunk introduces a section on interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste.
